channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pakistan Rearrests Ex-President Musharraf Over Red Mosque Deaths
item.description: The move came after former President Pervez Musharraf had been granted bail in three other cases and his lawyer said he was cleared to leave the country.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Myanmar, Once Shunned, Accepts Asean Leader Post
item.description: At the close of the East Asia Summit, Myanmar’s president, Thein Sein, formally assumed responsibility for hosting the meeting a year from now.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: India Ink: Oil Spills Becoming Frequent Hazard for Fishermen Near Mumbai
item.description: The livelihood of a fishing community in Uran region of Maharashtra is affected by frequent oil spills, the latest one caused by a pipeline burst on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Vaishnavi Mata Matsvyavsay Vividh Karyakari Society.
item.media:description: Fisherman in Uran, Maharashtra, skimming oil off the water surface and dumping it in recovery kits on Monday.

item.title: Conflicting Reports on Fairness of Azerbaijan Election
item.description: A delegation from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said it had documented widespread irregularities in Wednesday’s vote, but other observers disagreed.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Letter From Europe: A Spy Thriller, Now a Wife’s Endless Pain
item.description: The widow of Alexander V. Litvinenko, who was poisoned in 2006 with a radioactive isotope, has been blocked in her efforts to secure full disclosure about the circumstances of her husband’s death.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Wilfried Martens, Former Belgian Premier, Dies at 77
item.description: Mr. Martens led nine Belgian governments and the European Union’s Christian Democrat group.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Pakistani Student Wins Top European Human Rights Award
item.description: Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl who survived a Taliban assassination attempt a year ago, was chosen as the winner of the $65,000 Sakharov Prize.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: North Korean Leader Tightens Grip with Removal of Top General
item.description: Kim Jong-un engineered recent reshuffles to retire or sideline old generals and promote a new set of aides more loyal to him.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Libyan Prime Minister Is Kidnapped, Then Freed
item.description: Ali Zeidan, the prime minister, was “liberated” hours after he was seized early Thursday in apparent retaliation for the capture of a suspected Qaeda leader by American commandos.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ali Zeidan of Libya, center, after being freed by abductors on Thursday in Tripoli.

item.title: Migrant Boat Tragedy in Italy Complicates German Politics
item.description: In the search for a new German government, key figures in Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative party on Thursday demanded fresh European policies toward asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Study Finds Setbacks in Carbon Capture Projects
item.description: The number of large projects to capture and bury carbon dioxide has fallen, a report says, even though scientists say such projects are needed to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: Snowden’s Father Arrives in Moscow
item.description: Lon Snowden, the father of the fugitive National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, said he did not expect his son to return to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Criticism Over Israeli Plan for an Airport
item.description: Jordan criticized on Wednesday an Israeli plan to build a new international airport on the Red Sea, close to an existing one in Jordan.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Workers Doused With Radioactive Water
item.description: Six workers at the Fukushima nuclear plant were sprayed with highly radioactive water after they accidentally disconnected a pipe in the reactors’ makeshift cooling system, the plant’s operator said.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Soldier Hurt by Mortar Shells From Syria
item.description: An Israeli soldier was lightly wounded by shrapnel on Wednesday when two mortar shells fired from Syria hit a military post in the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Peacekeeping by U.N. Faces New Scrutiny on 2 Fronts
item.description: The United Nations was charged in a lawsuit with gross negligence in Haiti’s cholera epidemic, and accused by an anticorruption organization of oversight lapses in its own peacekeeping operations.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Fairness an Issue, Even After Azerbaijan Votes
item.description: Jamil Hasanli, who appeared headed to defeat in Azerbaijan’s presidential election, said a compressed campaign calendar was one obstacle in his attempt to deny Ilham Aliyev a third term.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Gulgez Jabrailova, 78, left, waited in her home as an election official checked her ID.

item.title: Extremist Group Gains Foothold Among Kenyans
item.description: Kenya’s slums have long provided a fertile recruiting ground for Muslim extremists, but analysts say that the Shabab have been finding recruits from across the country, not just in traditionally Muslim areas.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and JOSH KRON
item.media:description: The remains of a church in Mombasa, Kenya, set ablaze by Muslim extremists.

item.title: In Crackdown Response, U.S. Temporarily Freezes Some Military Aid to Egypt
item.description: The Obama administration announced a modest and temporary freeze on military assistance to Egypt, even as officials emphasized a desire to avoid rupturing a three-decade-old security relationship.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MARK LANDLER

item.title: 3 Arrested in Death of Tibetan Religious Leader in China
item.description: Choje Akong Rinpoche, a Tibetan Buddhist leader, apparently had an “economic dispute” with the suspects, the police said. His nephew and driver were also killed.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: As Drilling Practice Takes Off in U.S., Europe Proves Hesitant
item.description: The temptation to follow the United States in extracting shale gas from rock presents Europeans with contentious trade-offs.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: The designer Vivienne Westwood at a drilling site near Balcombe, south of London, in August.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For America, Life Was Cheap in Vietnam
item.description: The Vietnamese general Vo Nguyen Giap is remembered for his acceptance of enormous casualties. But American commanders were no less brutal.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK TURSE

item.title: Makhachkala Journal: A Russian Region Neither at War Nor at Peace, but Facing a Crackdown
item.description: Russian authorities, determined that nothing will mar the Olympics in Sochi, have been accused of human rights violations.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Makhachkala, the capital of Dagestan, in April. Russian authorities are picking up people suspected of being militants and detaining them without charges, human rights activists say.

item.title: Cutbacks in U.N. Food Assistance Set Off Outcry in Gaza
item.description: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency pointed to a $55 million budget shortfall and said the cuts were based on a re-evaluation of Gaza’s needs.
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: Europe Pledges Aid to Italy for Refugees
item.description: The European Union’s top official visited an Italian island where a boat capsized last week and announced that Italy would receive $40.5 million, to deal with refugees.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Roberto Salomone/European Commission, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: European delegates on Wednesday honored the victims of a shipwreck that killed hundreds.
